subtopics.title: What is GCP?
subtopics.theory:
Google Cloud Platform (GCP)

Definition: GCP is a suite of cloud computing services offered by Google that allows users to develop and manage applications and infrastructure on Google's global network.

Components of GCP:

  • Compute: Virtual machines, containers, and functions. (e.g., Compute Engine, Cloud Functions)
  • Storage: Cloud storage, databases, and object storage. (e.g., Cloud Storage, BigQuery, Cloud SQL)
  • Networking: Virtual private clouds, load balancers, and firewalls. (e.g., Virtual Private Cloud, Cloud Load Balancing, Cloud Firewall)
  • Big Data: Data processing, analytics, and machine learning. (e.g., BigQuery, Cloud Dataflow, Cloud ML Engine)
  • Other Services: Identity and access management, monitoring, and observability. (e.g., Cloud Identity, Cloud Monitoring, Cloud Trace)

Benefits of GCP:

  • On-Demand Resources: Scale computing resources up or down on demand.
  • Global Reach: Access services from multiple data centers around the world.
  • Pay-as-You-Go Pricing: Only pay for the resources you consume.
  • Built-in Security: Benefit from Google's security infrastructure and compliance certifications.
  • Managed Services: Focus on developing applications, while Google manages the underlying infrastructure.

Example:

A startup wants to build a web application that runs on a scalable and secure platform.

  • Compute: They use Compute Engine to create virtual machines for their application.
  • Storage: They store data in Cloud Storage and use Cloud SQL for their database.
  • Networking: They configure a Virtual Private Cloud for secure access.
  • Big Data: They use Cloud Dataflow for real-time data processing and BigQuery for data analytics.
  • Other Services: They use Cloud Monitoring to monitor application performance and Cloud Identity to manage user access.

By using GCP, the startup can quickly build and deploy their application on a secure and scalable platform, freeing them to focus on developing their product.
